Award.AwardTitle: Quantum Coherence Effects on Charge Generation in Organic Semiconductors
Award.AbstractNarration: A fundamental understanding of energy and charge transfer processes in organic semiconductors is critical to the development of versatile next-generation photonic and electronic technologies, such as light-emitting diodes, photovoltaics, and sensors. Coherence is a phenomenon resulting from the quantum nature of semiconductors that plays an important role in determining energy and charge migration pathways within these materials and thus influences device performance. However, the role of coherence in charge transfer remains underexplored. This project is investigating how coherences involving molecular vibrations assist charge generation following light absorption by organic semiconductors. The graduate student participants in this project are being educated using an integrated approach that trains them to be problem solvers. The students are being taught to prepare complex materials and at the same time are learning the physical techniques necessary to answer the questions addressed by their research. This approach is very effective in developing the kind of intellectual flexibility necessary to meet the rapidly changing roles of scientists in society. This project also engages the broader community through outreach to elementary schools through to the collegiate level to educate and inspire the next generation of scientists.<br/><br/>Organic semiconductors suitable for photonic device applications must be designed for ultrafast photo-driven electron-hole pair formation and subsequent rapid charge transport over long distances. Many such materials are based on electron donor-acceptor molecular components, such that optimizing the performance of organic semiconductors requires a fundamental understanding of the microscopic aspects of charge transfer in donor-acceptor systems at the quantum mechanical level. The primary goal of this project is to investigate whether vibrational and/or vibronic coherences assist symmetry-breaking charge generation following photoexcitation of organic semiconductors. The secondary goals of the project are to investigate 1) whether higher-order polygonal structures in solids, i.e. tilings and tessellations, lead to coherences that assist charge separation in organic semiconductors, and 2) whether excitonic coherences resulting from energy transfer processes in organic semiconductors influence subsequent charge transfer within them. While charge transfer is inherently quantum mechanical, many of the salient features of electron transfer kinetics have been treated classically. However, these treatments largely ignore the role of quantum coherences between states as they are typically very short lived (~10-100 fs for electronic states, up to several ps for vibrational/vibronic states) and as such are assumed to have decayed prior to electron transfer. However, with increasingly advanced spectroscopic techniques and improvements in time resolution, it is now possible to probe these processes on the requisite timescales and observe these coherences and their effects directly, which will aid in the design of high-performance organic semiconductors.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Developing a fundamental understanding of how to control charge transport in organic semiconductors is critical to the future of electronics, computers, and energy production. Organic materials offer the possibility of developing solutions that are not only versatile but are cost effective and environmentally benign as well.

Organic semiconductors suitable for photonic device applications must be designed for ultrafast photo-driven electron-hole pair formation and subsequent rapid charge transport over long distances. Many such materials are based on electron donor-bridge-acceptor (D-B-A) molecular components, such that optimizing the performance of organic semiconductors requires a fundamental understanding of the microscopic aspects of charge transfer in D-B-A systems at the quantum mechanical level. While charge transfer is inherently quantum mechanical, many of the salient features of electron transfer kinetics have been treated classically. However, these treatments largely ignore the role of quantum coherences between states as they are typically very short lived (~10-100 fs for electronic states, up to several ps for vibrational/vibronic states) and as such are assumed to have decayed prior to electron transfer. However, with increasingly advanced spectroscopic techniques and improvements in time resolution, it is now possible to probe processes on these timescales and observe these coherences and their effects directly, which will ultimately aid in the design of high performance organic semiconductors.

Coherence phenomena have been implicated in numerous energy transfer phenomena, but the role of coherence in charge transfer remains underexplored. Enhancing the performance of organic semiconductors, whose applications depend largely on charge transfer and transport requires developing a detailed understanding of the role that quantum coherence can play in determining the charge transfer and transport properties of these important materials. The primary accomplishments of this project were to identify vibrational and vibronic coherences that assist symmetry-breaking charge generation following photoexcitation of organic semiconductors. The secondary accomplishments of the project were to investigate higher-order polygonal structures in solids that lead to coherences that assist charge separation in organic semiconductors and identify excitonic coherences resulting from energy transfer processes in organic semiconductors that influence subsequent charge transfer.

Graduate education during this project focused on an integrated approach that encourages students to be problem solvers. The students are taught to prepare complex materials and at the same time learn the physical techniques necessary to answer the questions that are being addressed in their research. This approach has proven very effective in developing the kind of intellectual flexibility necessary to meet the rapidly changing roles of scientists in society. Regarding the development of human resources, we are particularly active in providing opportunities for women in science. Historically, we have been very successful in placing women scientists in excellent positions in academia, industry and consulting. Our students routinely volunteer in a variety of outreach programs, including “Science In The Classroom” SITC), which is centered on monthly engagement with 3rd/4th-graders at an elementary school (Hayt) in a historically under-served and diverse community in Chicago (Rogers Park). Approximately one third of the classes served by SITC are multilingual and learn English as a second language alongside regular curriculum. We are also active in a program called Letters to a Pre-Scientist which focuses on creating personal connections between middle school students from underprivileged schools and scientists to expose these students to science as a career by writing letters to a middle school pen pal about science. We also volunteer weekly with Northwestern's Science Club Mentor program which aims to teach middle school students about asking scientific questions and developing hypotheses through one-on-one mentorship. For the duration of their middle school career, we work with these students on guided scientific activities and even individual research projects. In addition, we are engaged at the high school level through Mentorship Opportunities for Research Engagement (MORE) advising students at Niles West High School (Skokie, IL) on independent research projects. We also contribute to the STEMed group at Northwestern, which focuses on college education issues and developments in the sciences. The group fosters a higher level of teaching by studying and putting into practice new teaching methods.
